reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central support for the essay’s relative optimism about “partial AM-convergence + trade/compromise”: that advanced AI and iron-clad contracts can make moral trade low-friction and reliably implement morally loaded bargains. If that assumption fails systematically due to specification gaming, the essay’s most promising pathway to mostly-great futures (section 3) is significantly weakened—though the broader essay doesn’t fully collapse because it also discusses other routes (WAM-convergence, self-interest dynamics) and multiple blockers (including threats) independently. The argument’s strength is moderate: adversarial optimization / Goodhart-style failures are a real, paper-relevant concern for contract-based moral trade, but it doesn’t fully refute moral trade because some trades can be structured as direct resource partitioning (less proxy-dependent), can include iterative adjudication/renegotiation, and may leverage shared superintelligent verification rather than brittle metrics. Correctness is fairly high: the critique’s core claim (specification attacks are a serious risk when optimizing contractible proxies of welfare/value) is plausibly true, though it overstates inevitability (“collapses or dominated by deception”) and under-engages with possible robustness mechanisms. It is clear, tightly focused, and contains little extraneous material.
title: Superintelligent optimization enables specification gaming that collapses moral trade
